functions:
sql.logical.and AND AND (${column} ${condition} ${value}) ${moreconditions}
Inside IF we will use AND condition .performs a logical conjunction on two expressions. In 'column' paramter we will 'drag column'. In 'condition' parameter provide conditions like (>,= etc.,like). In 'value' parameter provide condition value. In 'moreconditions' parameter we will use nested 'OR' condition , 'AND' conditions. Example: CASE WHEN 'Washington' like '%sh%' AND 'Washington' like 'W%' THEN 'return washington' else 'NotMatched' end
sql.logical.case CASE (CASE ${condition} END)
Inside case we will use when condition. Evaluates each condition from left to right and returns the result when the first condition met. If no condition met return from else if exist, otherwise return null. Example : CASE WHEN Quantity > 30 THEN "The quantity is greater than 30" ELSE "The quantity is under 30" END
sql.logical.else ELSE ELSE ${statement_list}
Returns from statement_list when condition gets fail.We will use ELSE inside case function. Example: CASE when 50 > 0 then 'true' else 'false'
sql.logical.elseif ELSEIF (case when ${column} ${condition} ${value} then ${conditiontrue} when ${elseIfcolumn} ${elseIfcondition} ${elseIfvalue} then ${elseIfconditiontrue} else ${conditionfalse} ${moreconditions} end)
Evaluates conditions and returns 'conditiontrue' if condition is true, otherwise return 'conditionfalse'. We will use nested condition inside else 'conditiontrue' parameter. Example:case when creditlim > 50000 then 'PLATINUM' else when (creditlim > = 50000) then 'GOLD' else 'SILVER' end
sql.logical.if IF (case when ${column} ${condition} ${value} ${moreconditions} then ${conditiontrue} else ${conditionfalse} end)
Inside IF we will use AND, OR conditions. Evaluates and returns 'conditiontrue' if condition is true, otherwise return 'conditionfalse'. In 'column' paramter we will drag column. In 'condition' parameter provide conditions like (>,= etc.,). In 'value' parameter provide value. In 'moreconditions' parameter we will use nested 'OR', 'AND' conditions. Instead of dragging column directly we will write expression in column parameter like 50 > 0 (Note : In such case don't provide anything in 'condition' parameter and 'value' parameter). Example : IF (creditlim > 50000) 'PLATINUM','SILVER'
sql.logical.ifnull IFNULL (coalesce(${expr1}, ${expr2}))
Returns Expr1 if it is not null otherwise return expr2. Example : IFNULL(profit, 0)
sql.logical.iif IIF (case when ${column} ${condition} ${value} then ${conditiontrue} else ${conditionfalse} end)
Evaluates and returns 'conditiontrue' if condition is true, otherwise return 'conditionfalse'. Example : case when 'washington'like 'W%' then 'true' else 'false' end
sql.logical.isnull ISNULL IS NULL
Inside WHEN condition we will use ISNULL. Evalutes and returns 'Conditiontrue' if the expression contain Null. Example1 : CASE WHEN 1 ISNULL THEN Conditionfalse. Example2 : CASE WHEN NULL ISNULL THEN Conditiontrue
sql.logical.not NOT NOT(${column} ${condition} ${value})
Evaluates and returns 'conditiontrue' if condition is false, otherwise returns 'conditionfalse'. We will use NOT inside IF. Example : NOT(500 > 1000) result :true
sql.logical.or OR OR ${column} ${condition} ${value} ${moreconditions}
Performs a logical disjunction on two expressions. In 'column' paramter we will drag column. In 'condition' parameter provide conditions like (>,= etc.,). In 'value' parameter provide value. In 'moreconditions' parameter we will use nested 'OR' , 'AND' functions. Instead of dragging column directly we will write expression in column parameter like 50 > 0 in such case don't provide anything in 'condition' and 'value' parameter. We will use OR inside IF. Example : CASE WHEN 'Washington' like '%sh%' OR 'Washington' like 'W%' THEN 'return washington' else 'NotMatched' end
sql.logical.when WHEN WHEN ${column} ${searchcondition} ${value} THEN ${statement_list} ${moreconditions}
Returns 'statement_list' when condition get satisfied . In column paramter we will drag column. In searchcondition parameter provide conditions like (>, =, IS Null etc .,). In value parameter provide value(Note : IS Null used in 'condition' parameter then don't provide anything in 'value' parameter). In moreconditions parameter we will use nested when conditions, Else condition . We will use WHEN inside CASE. Example1 : CASE WHEN 1 > 0 THEN 'one' else 'TWO'. Example2 : CASE WHEN 'Singapore' IS NULL THEN 'Singa' ELSE 'pore'. Example3 : CASE WHEN Washington like '%sh%' THEN 'return washington' else 'NotMatched'
sql.logical.zn ZN (CASE WHEN ${expr} IS NULL THEN '0' ELSE ${expr} end)
Returns "expression" if it is not null, otherwise returns zero.Example :ZN(null) result :0
sql.numeric.acos ACOS acos(${number})
Returns the arc cosine of number. Example: acos(0.25) result: 1.318116071652818
sql.numeric.asin ASIN asin(${number})
Returns the arc sine of number. Example: asin(0.25) result: 0.25268025514207865
sql.numeric.atan ATAN atan(${number})
Returns the arc tangent of number. Example: atan(0.25) result: 0.24497866312686414
sql.numeric.round ROUND round(${number}, ${decimalpoint})
Returns number rounded to the nearest integer. Example: round(34.4158,2) result: 34.42
sql.numeric.ceiling CEILING ceiling(${number})
Returns number rounded up to the nearest integer. Example: ceiling(0.25) result: 1
sql.numeric.cos COS cos(${number})
Returns the cosine of number. Example: cos(0.25) result: 0.9689124217106447
sql.numeric.cot COT 1/tan(${number})
Returns the cotangent of an angle. Specify the angle in radians. Example: cot(0.25) result: 3.9163173646459399
sql.numeric.degrees DEGREES degrees(${number})
Converts angle number in radians to degrees. Example: degrees(0.25) result: 14.32394487827058
sql.numeric.div DIV (${dividend} / NULLIF(${divisor}, 0))
Returns the integer part of a division operation. Example: div(10,5) result: 2
sql.numeric.exp EXP exp(${number})
Returns Eulerâ€™s number raised to the power of the given number. Example: exp(2) result: 7.389
sql.numeric.floor FLOOR floor(${number})
Returns number rounded down to the nearest number. Example: floor(3.1415) result: 3
sql.numeric.ln LN log(${number})
Returns the natural logarithm of number. Example: log(2) result: 0.6931471805599453
sql.numeric.max MAX greatest(${number1},${number2})
Returns the largest of the provided values. Example: greatest(4,13) result: 13
sql.numeric.min MIN least(${number1},${number2})
Returns the smallest of the provided values. Example: least(13,4) result: 4
sql.numeric.pi PI pi
Returns the constant Pi.
sql.numeric.log LOG log(10,${number})
log() function is used to return the base 10 logarithm of a given number or logarithm of a number for a particular base, as specified in the argument. Example: log(10,2) result: 0.30102999566398114
sql.numeric.sign SIGN sign(${number})
Returns the signum function of number, that is: 0 if the argument is 0, 1 if the argument is greater than 0, -1 if the argument is less than 0. Example: sign(0.5) result: 1.
sql.numeric.sin SIN sin(${number})
Returns the sine of number. Example: sin(0.25) result: 0.24740395925452294
sql.numeric.pow POWER pow(${number},${exponent})
Displays the value of a number raised to the power of another number. Example: power(4,2) result: 16
sql.numeric.radians RADIANS radians(${number})
Converts the value of a number from degrees to radians. Example : radians(4) result : 0.06981317007977318
sql.numeric.sqrt SQRT sqrt(${number})
Displays the square root of a non-negative number. Example: sqrt(5) result: 2.23606797749979
sql.numeric.square SQUARE (${number} * ${number})
It displays the square of a given number. Example: square(4) result: 16
sql.numeric.tan TAN tan(${number})
Returns the tangent of number. Example: tan(0.25) result: 0.25534192122103627
sql.numeric.truncate TRUNCATE trunc(${number},${digit})
Returns number rounded to integer by dropping digits after decimal point. Example: trunc(1.289,2) result: 1.28
sql.numeric.abs ABS ABS(${number})
It returns the absolute value of a number. Example: abs(-24)Result: 24
sql.text.concat CONCAT CONCAT(${string1},${string2})
Returns the concatenation of column, text. Example: CONCAT('Beng',aluru) result : Bengaluru. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.text.contains CONTAINS (case when (position(${substring} IN ${string})> 0) then true else false end)
Returns true if the given string contains the specified substring. Example : case when (position('aluru' IN 'Bengaluru')> 0) then 'true' else 'false' end result:true
sql.text.ascii ASCII ascii(${string})
Returns the Unicode of the first character of string. Example: ASCII('A') result:65
sql.text.char CHAR chr(${number})
Returns the character encoded by the ASCII code. Example: CHAR(65) result: A
sql.text.endswith ENDSWITH case when(${string} like concat('%',${substring})) then true else false end
Returns true if the given string endswith specified substring. Example:case when('postgres' like concat('%','res')) then true else false end result: true. Note:Please provide single quotes if you are directly typing the substring value.
sql.text.startswith STARTSWITH case when(${string} like concat(${substring},'%')) then true else false end
Returns true if string starts with substring. Example: case when('bengaluru' like concat('ben','%')) then true else false end result: true. Note:Please provide single quotes if you are directly typing the substring value.
sql.text.find FIND position(${substring} IN ${string})
Returns the starting position of the first instance of substring in string. Positions start with 1. If not found, 0 is returned. Example :position('z','Bengaluru') result : 0, position('aluru','Bengaluru') result : 5
sql.text.lower LOWER LOWER(${string})
Converts all characters in the specified string to lowercase. Example: LOWER('BENGALURU') result: bengaluru. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.text.length LENGTH LENGTH(${string})
Returns the number of characters in string. Example: length('Bengaluru') result:9
sql.text.lpad LPAD LPAD(${string},${length}, ${padString})
This function Pads the string to the length specified by prepending the fill or a space. Truncates the string if longer than the specified length. NOTE:string,padString value(s) should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg:LPAD('XYZ Tech',24,'I am working in') result: 'I am working in XYZ Tech'
sql.text.ltrim LTRIM LTRIM(${string})
This function removes any characters from the beginning of column that matches the characters in matchingStr. NOTE:column value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg:LTRIM('XYZ Tech') result: Z Tech
sql.text.left LEFT substr(${string},1, ${length})
Returns the left most (length) character from the string . Example: substr('bengaluru',1, 4) result: beng
sql.text.right RIGHT substr(${string},(length(${string})+1)-${length}, length(${string}))
Returns the rightmost character from the string.Example: substr('Bengaluru', (length('Bengaluru')+1)-3, length('Bengaluru')) result: uru
sql.text.trim TRIM TRIM(${string})
Removes whitespace from both side of the given string. Note: column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg: TRIM(' HOME TecH ') result: 'HOME TecH'.
sql.text.rpad RPAD RPAD(${string},${length},${padString})
This function returns a string that is right-padded with a specified string to a certain length to the column. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg:RPAD('I am working in', 24, XYZ Tech) result: I am working in XYZ Tech
sql.text.mid MID substring(${string},${position},${length})
Returns the string starting from specified position. If position is more than string or length is less than 1 it will return empty string. Example: substring('bengaluru',2,5); result: engal
sql.text.reverse REVERSE reverse(${string})
Returns string with the characters in reverse order. Example: REVERSE('Bengaluru') result : urulagneB
sql.text.replace REPLACE replace(${string},${substring},${replacestring})
String search for substring and replace it with replacestring. If substring is not found, the string is not changed. Example: REPLACE('bengaluru','b','Z') result: zengaluru
sql.dateTime.quarter QUARTER cast(ceil(EXTRACT(month from ${datetime})/3.0)as integer)
Returns the quarter of the year for date/datetime. Example: cast(ceil(extract(month from timestamp '2014-03-08 12:20:19')/3.0)as integer) result:1
sql.text.rtrim RTRIM RTRIM(${string})
Removes trailing whitespace from stringNOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg:RTRIM('XYZ Tech' ,ch) result: XYZ
sql.text.space SPACE rpad(' ',${noOfSpace},' ')
Returns a string consisting of space characters. Example: space(6) result: .
sql.text.split SPLIT (REPLACE(SUBSTRING(SUBSTRING_INDEX(${string}, ${delimiter}, ${index}), LENGTH(SUBSTRING_INDEX(${string}, ${delimiter}, ${index} -1)) + 1), ${delimiter}, ''))
Splits string on delimiter and returns the field index. Field indexes start with 1. If the index is larger than the number of fields, then empty will return Example : (REPLACE(SUBSTRING(SUBSTRING_INDEX('Singa$Pore$Benga$Luru', '$', 2),LENGTH(SUBSTRING_INDEX('Singa$Pore$Benga$luru', '$', 2 -1)) + 1),'$', '')) result : Pore. Note : This function will not work with `'` in string.
sql.text.findnth FINDNTH (case when SUBSTRING_INDEX(${string}, ${substring}, ${th_appeareance})=${string} then null else (instr(${string},SUBSTRING_INDEX(${string}, ${substring}, ${th_appeareance}))+length(substring_index(${string}, ${substring},${th_appeareance}))) end)
Returns the position of the nth occurrence of substring within the specified string, where th_appeareance is defined by the occurrence argument. Example : case when SUBSTRING_INDEX('calculation', 'c', 2)='calculation' then null else (instr('calculation',SUBSTRING_INDEX('calculation', 'c', 2))+length(substring_index('calculation', 'c',2))) end result : 4.note: null value indicates absence of the substring.
sql.text.upper UPPER UPPER(${string})
Converts all characters in a string to uppercase.UPPER('bengaluru') - BENGALURU. NOTE:str should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
CAST(DATE_ADD(timestamp '2014-03-08 11:10:27', interval '2' year) AS timestamp)
sql.dateTime.datetimeadd DATETIMEADD CAST(DATE_ADD(${datetime}, interval ${value} ${unit}) as timestamp)
Returns the specified datetime with the specified number interval added to the date_part of that datetime. Example:CAST(DATE_ADD(timestamp '2014-03-08 11:10:27', interval '2' year) AS timestamp) result:2016-03-08 11:10:27.000000 supported units:second, minute , hour , day , month , year.
sql.dateTime.datetimediff DATETIMEDIFF DATE_PART(${unit}, ${datetime1}) - DATE_PART(${unit}, ${datetime2})
Returns the difference between date1 and date2 expressed in terms of unit. Example: DATE_PART(year, timestamp '2014-03-08 11:10:27') - DATE_PART(year, timestamp '2019-03-08 11:10:27');result: -5
sql.dateTime.makedatetime MAKEDATETIME (case when length(${year}) <> 0 OR length(${month}) <> 0 OR length(${day}) <> 0 OR length(${hour}) <> 0 OR length(${minute}) <> 0 OR length(${second}) <> 0 then CAST(concat(${year},'-', ${month},'-',${day},' ', ${hour},':', ${minute},':', ${second}) as timestamp) else null end)
Returns a datetime that combines a year,month,day,hour,min,sec. Example: case when length('2013') greaterthanLessthan 0 OR length('07') greaterthanLessthan 0 OR length('15') greaterthanLessthan 0 OR length('08') greaterthanLessthan 0 OR length('15') greaterthanLessthan 0 OR length('23') greaterthanLessthan 0 then CAST(concat('2013','-', '07','-','15',' ', '08',':', '15',':', '23') as timestamp) else null end result: 2013-7-15 8-15-23. Note : Replace greaterthanLessthan with greaterthanLessthan symbols.
sql.dateTime.datetimepart DATETIMEPART EXTRACT(${unit} from ${datetime})
Returns an integer that represents the specified datepart(unit) of the specified datetime. Example: EXTRACT(day from timestamp '2014-03-08 09:12:30.123') Results: 8. supported unit for timestamp type :YEAR, MONTH, DAY,HOUR,MINUTE,SECOND. supported unit for date type :YEAR, MONTH, DAY
sql.dateTime.format FORMAT to_char(${datetime}, ${format})
Return a DATETIME format as a string. Example1: to_char(timestamp '2014-03-08 09:00:00', 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss') result: 2014-03-08 09:00:00. Note : In case of milliseconds use yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS format
sql.dateTime.week WEEK cast(TO_CHAR(${datetime}, 'w') as integer)
Returns the ISO week of the year for date/dateTime. The value ranges from 1 to 53 or 1 to 52. Example: cast(to_char(timestamp '2014-03-08 09:00:00','w')as integer) result: 10
sql.date.dateadd DATEADD CAST(DATE_ADD(${date}, interval ${value} ${unit}) AS DATE)
Returns the specified date with the specified number of interval added to the specified date_part of that date.Example:CAST(DATE_ADD(date '2014-03-08', interval '2' year) AS DATE) result:2016-03-08 supported units:day, month, year.
sql.date.datepart DATEPART DATE_PART(${unit},${date})
Returns an integer that represents the specified datepart of the specified date. Example: ('day', '2015-04-02') returns 2. supported date_part:YEAR, MONTH, DAY. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.dateTime.day DAY EXTRACT(day from ${datetime})
Returns day of the month for date/datetime. Example: EXTRACT(day from timestamp '2014-03-08 09:00:00')/EXTRACT(day from date '2014-03-08') result: 8
sql.date.datediff DATEDIFF DATE_PART(${unit}, ${date1}) - DATE_PART(${unit}, ${date2})
Returns the difference between date1 and date2 expressed in terms of unit. Example: DATE_PART('year', date '2014-03-08') - DATE_PART(year, date '2019-03-08');result: -5
sql.date.today TODAY (CURRENT_DATE)
Displays Current date.
sql.dateTime.hour HOUR EXTRACT(hour from ${datetime})
Return hour for timestamp. Example: EXTRACT(hour from timestamp '2014-03-08 12:20:19') result:12
sql.dateTime.minute MINUTE EXTRACT(minute from ${datetime})
Returns minute for timestamp. Example: EXTRACT(minute from timestamp from '2014-03-08 12:20:19') result: 20
sql.date.datetrunc DATETRUNC DATE_TRUNC(${unit},${date})
Truncates the specified date to the accuracy specified by the unit. Example: DATE_TRUNC('year', date '2014-03-08'). result:2014-01-01 00:00:00.000
sql.dateTime.datetimetrunc DATETIMETRUNC DATE_TRUNC(${unit}, ${datetime})
Truncates the specified datetime to the accuracy specified by the unit. Example: DATE_TRUNC('year', TIMESTAMP '2014-03-08 12:20:19). result:2014-01-01 00:00:00.000
sql.dateTime.month MONTH EXTRACT(month from ${datetime})
Returns the month of the year for date/datetime. Example: EXTRACT(month from timestamp '2007-02-03 09:00:00')/EXTRACT(month from date '2007-02-03') result:2
sql.dateTime.monthname MONTHNAME TO_CHAR(${datetime}, 'MMMM')
Returns MONTHNAME from date/datetime.Example: TO_CHAR(timestamp '2014-03-08 09:00:00', 'MMMM') result: MARCH
sql.dateTime.now NOW now()
Displays Current date and time. This function equivalent to current_timestamp.
sql.dateTime.second SECOND EXTRACT(second from ${datetime})
Returns the second for timestamp. Example:EXTRACT(second from timestamp '2014-03-08 12:20:19') result: 19
sql.dateTime.year YEAR EXTRACT(year from ${datetime})
Return year for date/dateTime. Example: EXTRACT(year from timestamp '2014-03-08 09:00:00')/EXTRACT(year from date '2014-03-08') result: 2014
sql.dateTime.makedate MAKEDATE case when length(${year}) <> 0 OR length(${month}) <> 0 OR length(${day}) <> 0 then cast(concat(${year},'-',${month},'-',${day}) AS date ) else null end
Returns a date for given year, month and day. Example: case when length('2013') greaterthanLessthan 0 OR length('07') greater than less than 0 OR length('15') greater than less than 0 then cast(concat('2013','-','07','-','15') AS date ) else null end result : 2013-07-15 Note : Replace greaterthanLessthan with greaterthanLessthan symbols.
sql.dateTime.dayofweek DAYOFWEEK cast(TO_CHAR(${datetime},'e')as integer)
Returns the ISO day of the week for date/datetime. The value ranges from 1 (monday) to 7 (sunday). Example:cast(TO_CHAR(timestamp '2019-12-11 10:11:20','e')as integer) Result:3
sql.dateTime.dayname DAYNAME to_char(${datetime},'EEEE')
Returns the name of the week day for date/dateTime. Example: TO_CHAR(timestamp '2014-03-08 09:12:30.123','EEEE')) result: 'Saturday'.
sql.dateTime.parse PARSE to_timestamp(${string},${format})
Takes a string as input and displays a dateTime. Example:to_timestamp('2008-01-31 10:32:22','yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss') result: 2008-01-31 10:32:22
sql.dateTime.maketime MAKETIME (case when length(${hour}) <> 0 OR length(${minute}) <> 0 OR length(${second}) <> 0 then CAST(concat(${hour},':',${minute},':',${second}) as TIME) else null end)
Returns time value from the hour, minute and seconds.Example: case when length('12') greater than less than 0 OR length('30') greater than less than 0 OR length('40') greater than less than 0 then CAST(concat('12',':','30',':','40') as TIME) else null end Note : Replace greater than less than with greater than less than symbols result: 12:30:40
sql.dateTime.millisecond MILLISECOND cast(TO_CHAR(${datetime}, 'SSS') as integer)
Returns the millisecond for the second for dateTime. Example: cast(TO_CHAR(timestamp '2014-03-08 09:12:30.123','SSS') as integer) result : 123
sql.time.timeAdd TIMEADD DATE_ADD(time ${column}, interval ${value} ${unit})
This function helps in date addition Column can be date,time and timestamp, integer can be expression also. Eg: ('10:55:55',interval '2' hour) returns 12:55:55. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.time.timeSub TIMESUB DATE_SUB(time ${column}, interval ${integer} ${unit})
This function helps in date subtracts Column can be date,time and timestamp, integer can be expression also. Eg: ('10:55:55',interval '2' minute) returns 10:57:55. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.time.time_to_char TIMETOCHAR TO_CHAR(CAST(${column} AS TIME), ${format})
Convert a time to a string. Ex:TO_CHAR('12:20:30','HH mm ss') result:12 20 30. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.json.index INDEX ${column}[${index}]
This function can be applied on array type to fetch the array[index] value
sql.json.property KEY_VALUE (${column}.`${property}`)
This function can be applied on json type to fetch the value for a key
sql.nestedData.flatten FLATTEN flatten(${value})
Having used the FLATTEN function to break down arrays into distinct rows, you can run queries that do deeper analysis on the flattened result set.
sql.nestedData.kvgen KEY_VALUE_GENERATION kvgen(${value})
KVGEN turns a map with a wide set of columns into an array of key-value pairs.Note:KVGEN doesn't support object with heterogeneous values and object with array values.
sql.typeConversion.cast CAST CAST(${column} AS ${dataType})
Cast function converts one dataType to another datatype. Note:All Values should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg: CAST('2019-03-22 17:34:03.000' AS char) result:2019-03-22 17:34:03.000
sql.typeConversion.tochar TOCHAR CONCAT(CAST(${column} as VARCHAR),'')
This function is used to convert date,number,dateTime,time,interval to string. NOTE:field should be in single quotes if you are typing the string/data/dateTime/time/interval value.Eg:CAST(456 as VARCHAR(3)) result:'456'
sql.typeConversion.tonum TONUM 1* CAST((case when REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') <>'' then REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') end) AS INTEGER)
This function is used to convert character based integer value to integer type.(format is not required)Eg:CAST('456' as INTEGER)) result:456
sql.typeConversion.todate TODATE CAST(case when REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') <>'' then ${column} end as DATE)
This function is used to convert character based date value to date type.(format is not required)Eg:CAST('2018-08-30' as DATE)) result:2018-08-30
sql.typeConversion.todatetime TODATETIME CAST(case when REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') <>'' then ${column} end as TIMESTAMP)
This function is used to convert character based dateTime value to dateTime type.(format is not required)Eg:CAST('2018-08-30 10:15:30' as TIMESTAMP)) result:2018-08-30 10:15:30
sql.typeConversion.totime TOTIME CAST(case when REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') <>'' then ${column} end as TIME)
This function is used to convert character based time value to time type.(format is not required)Eg:CAST('10:15:30' as TIME) result:10:15:30
sql.other.coalesce COALESCE COALESCE(${expr1},${expr2})
This function returns the first non-NULL expression among its arguments.If all expressions evaluate to null, then the COALESCE function returns null. NOTE:expressions should be in single quotes if you are typing value.
sql.other.nullif NULLIF NULLIF(${expr1},${expr2})
This function compares two expressions.If expr1 and expr2 are equal, then returns NULL. Otherwise, it returns expr1. NOTE: All Expressions should be in single quotes if you are typing value.
sql.conditional.case CASE (CASE WHEN ${actualValue} ${operator} ${expectedValue} THEN ${assignValue} ELSE ${elseValue} END)
This function compares 'actualValue' and 'expectedValue' based on the operator if condition succeeds then changes the 'actualValue' to 'assignValue' else 'elseValue'. Note:All Values should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.conditional.case_not_equals CASE_NOT_EQUALS (CASE WHEN ${actualValue} <>${compareValue} THEN ${changeValue} ELSE ${actualValue} END)
This function compares 'actualValue' and 'compareValue' if both are not equal then changes the 'actualValue' to 'changeValue' other wise 'actualValue' remains same. Note:All Values should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.text.dateToString dateToString to_char(${column}, 'yyyy-MM-dd')
Converts the date to string
sql.text.numericToString numericToString CAST(${column} AS VARCHAR)
Converts the number to string
sql.text.dateTimeToString dateTimeToString to_char(${column}, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
Converts the datetime to string
sql.text.timeToString timeToString to_char(${column}, 'HH:mm:ss')
Converts the time to string
sql.text.otherToString otherToString CAST(${column} as VARCHAR)
Converts the number,date,dateTime,time to string.Eg:CAST(120) RESULTS:'120'.NOTE: column's value should be in quotes if the values is manually typing and its data type is "text/date/dateTime/time" type
sql.typeConversion.typeof TYPEOF typeof(${column})
Returns the dataType of column.Note:typeof function only works with columns only.
sql.text.ilike ILIKE ILIKE(${column}, '${matchingStr}')
This function Compares argument one and two and returns true if values match. Eg:('abc', 'abc') returns true. NOTE: matchingStr must be a constant. NOTE:Column's value should be in single quotes if your are typing.
sql.text.initcap INITCAP INITCAP(${column})
This function returns the string by converting each word 1st char into uppercase. Eg: ('apache drill release 1.0') returns Apache Drill Release 1.0. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.text.strpos STRPOS STRPOS(${column},'${string}')
This function returns the location of the string in a column. Ex:('Apache Drill', 'Drill') will return 8. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.typeConversion.todecimal castToDecimal 1* CAST((case when REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') <>'' then REGEXP_REPLACE(${column},'[\n\r]', '') end) AS DECIMAL(${size}))
This function is used to convert character based decimal value to decimal type.(format is not required)Eg:CAST('456.34' as DECIMAL(5,2))) result:456.34
sql.dateTime.dateTimeSub DATETIME_SUB DATE_SUB(${column}, interval '${integer}' ${unit})
This function helps in date subtracts Column can be date,time and timestamp, integer can be expression also. Eg: ('2015-04-15 10:55:55',interval 2 minute) returns 2015-04-15 10:57:55. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
sql.dateTime.age AGE CAST(AGE(${datetime1} , ${datetime2}) AS VARCHAR)
This function Returns the interval between two timestamps or subtracts a timestamp from midnight of the current date. NOTE: Values should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.Eg:AGE(timestamp '2018-05-20 10:30:20',timestamp '2017-05-20 11:40:30')result :1 year 0 months 4 days 22:49:50
sql.dateTime.extractTime EXTRACT_TIME TO_TIME(case when REGEXP_REPLACE(SUBSTR(to_char(${dateTimeColumn}, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss'),${timeStartIndex},${timeEndIndex}),'[\n\r]', '') <>'' then REGEXP_REPLACE(SUBSTR(to_char(${dateTimeColumn}, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss'),${timeStartIndex},${timeEndIndex}),'[\n\r]', '') end , '${timeFormat}')
This function extracts time value from the given dataTime value.Ex:('2018-08-20 07:09:34') results:'07:09:34' NOTE:dateTimeColumn values should be in single quote if the you are typing the value.
sql.dateTime.timeOfDay TIME_OF_DAY TIMEOFDAY()
Returns the local date and time with time zone information.
sql.date.dateSub DATE_SUB DATE_SUB(${column}, interval '${integer}' ${unit})
This function helps in date subtracts Column can be date,time and timestamp, integer can be expression also. Eg: (date '2015-05-15',interval 2 month) returns 2015-03-15. NOTE:column's value should be in single quotes if you are typing the value.
